div.head: To make the ashes of flowers and plants leave molds
div.ab: Some mix put quicksilver inside it. But, if it is a little work, or fine & delicate foliage, that only has p a slender issue, they make two errors: the first, that quicksilver by its heaviness can break f some delicate feature inside when shaked, the other, that some grains will always linger inside that will make metals sour & hinder the perfection of the cast. It is true that if it is to empty the mold of some animal which is large & which has big conduits & passages by which the quicksilver can easily exit, like a bird or a serpent, one can indeed put in it some quicksilverpou to break by shaking the calcinated bones of the animal, because the aforesaid â˜¿ will come out & not remain at all.

left-top The asparagus stalk is so hard that most often it remains as charcoal. Because of this, dry it out beforehand, or wet it with oil of sulfur & turpentine, or cast separately the little branches & solder them onto a fat stalk drawn through by the wire drawing bench.

left-middle If the burnt thing has left some filth or ash, let it cool a little, & with an iron wire wrapped in cotton that can bend according to the cavities that you have to look for, clean & blow this flaw, or with a soft brush or a clipped pinceau.

They can be cast well in gold. But if you want to enamel them, you have to make them by hand & enamel them & then attach them. Otherwise, the leaves would be so pressured that the enamel mix together there.

div.head: Sand that has served
div.ab: Do not cast it. But because it is mixed with stone allum, you can use it in the mixture of others & it can serve in place of brick.

div.head: Molding en noyau wax figures or lead medals
div.ab: Rub them with oil with a pinceau, but let it be so lightly that the medal is almost rubbed dry & that it hardly appears to have been smeared. After destr rub it with eau de vye and heat the water with which you will wet your aforementionned sand, with plaster, brick & alum, in order that being chau like lukewarm when you cast it, the oil will not refuse it, as it does with cold water, & do not forget when moistening your sand to always miw in it a little sal ammoniac.
left-bottom Medals mold thusly very neatly.

If you have to cut some snake inside a mold in order to burn it, cut it far from the intake of the mold so that no blood at all remains, because it makes a crust that afterwards would not be taken away by the same quicksilver & removes impressions from your mold.
